And today, just 5% of women are CEOs in the world’s largest corporations. So how can the private sector help shift these barriers? Sarah Iqbal from the World Bank again. SI One is actually to concentrate on the issue, to discuss it, to talk about it, and to build a pipeline for women to get into leadership roles. In general, women tend to have different styles than men –and it’s not that one is better or worse, but rather that one is accounted for and the other is not. So, for example, women may not push their way forward in the workforce in the same way as men. And I think what the private sector can do is really account for that, really set up programmes that increase gender diversity in the workforce. LF Felicite Rwemalika is from Rwanda, and is a CEO and founder of the Organisation of Women in Sports, whose main objective is empowering women through football. She recalls her path to a position of leadership. FR What I can say that women have sometimes the potential and they don’t have the chance to express it out. My time came when my husband left me and went to liberate Rwanda. As a nurse, you cannot look after the four children and take them to school and look after you. So I set up a restaurant. I had a restaurant, I could work in the hospital in the morning, they even got the restaurant. So within those four years, this is when I realised I had the potential of being an entrepreneur. I had the potential of speaking out because of what I went through. So as time went on, I realised I could do business, I could speak out, I could try to see people changing their minds. I think it took me about 10 years to be accepted in the National Football Federation whereby I’m the president of the Women’s Football Commission, which didn’t exist before. And I’m on the board of the International Olympic Committee. And I won an award as an Ashoka fellow. So all this is just because I had a new idea of empowering women through sports, to expel the cultural and social beliefs that hinders or limits women’s participation into the country’s development. LF Let’s go back to Sarah Iqbal from the World Bank. SI You see a lot of girls predominantly working in sectors or moving towards sectors where women predominate. So, for example, on the healthcare and education fields, which are both great, but the question is – girls should be able to work in any field that they want to whether it’s a stem field, whether it’s healthcare, education, whether it’s entrepreneurship. Education is a key building block in determining what girls’ aspirations are for their future lives. We’ve seen actually really interesting models of where the private sector works with universities, works with secondary and tertiary education to actually increase the pipeline for girls and women in certain sectors. LF Habiba Mohamed is the team leader at the Centre for Girls’ Education in Nigeria. HM I think the first step is for the government of Nigeria to be able to support the public schools in a way that the teachers are trained, the quality of the education in the school is very good, so that when these girls graduate from secondary school they are able to get the certificates that will qualify them to move to higher institutions. Like our first cohort of girls when they graduated I think it were … We had very few of them that were able to meet the criteria of moving to higher institutions. We need not only the support from their parents, but the government has to support to train the teachers and to be able to make life easier for the girls when it comes to education. One is Amina Ussef, she was one of the girls that we sponsored into secondary school. And she has completed her secondary school, she has been trained as a girl ambassador. She is a cascading mentor in the organisation. And when Malala came to Nigeria to talk to our president about the Chibok girls, Amina was one of the two girls that were there to meet with Malala. During this UN SDG the Malala fund again invited Amina to be one of the five girls that supported Malala when she spoke at the United Nations. I was there to meet her. AU I’m Amina Ussef from Nigeria. HM The girl, Amina, always say if I hadn’t gone to school nobody would have even known that I exist. MY And I am Malala from Pakistan. HM Most of the girls admire the teenager Malala because they feel that if she is in a position to speak on behalf of millions of girls in the world, why won’t they stand and speak for Nigerian girls too? So I think it is something that is motivational. LF Positive role models have proven to be a great motivator for younger girls. And for many women their first female role model is their mothers. Back at the Trust Women conference, Gila, Khawla and Suha agreed. GR I think my mother was my role model because she’s a really strong woman and she always worked even though she had two children on her own. SZ I feel my mother, she’s a great woman. She take care of 11 children and she work, she’s religious but she never told me to cover my hair, for example. And to not participate in any activities that I like to be part of. KQ Same here. My mum is my role model. She just went against traditions and society to have us get a really good education, and practise her own rights. And I really look up for her because she fought for her own rights. GR As you can see, the three of us, we are successful women and we had strong role models. So if you don’t have a role model at home, I think it’s important for social workers, teachers to be role models. LF Isha Johansen in Sierra Leone gets inspiration from the strength of women around her. IJ For me, I think, the real people who have inspired me are the women of Africa, and just how they stand up for themselves up against adversity, and we have a lot of it. From conceiving, to childbirth, to fighting Ebola, fighting wars and wanting to fight for your place in society. So looking at these women, they’re not complaining, they’re just getting on with things and striving and surviving. They’re my role models and they inspire me. LF Habiba Mohamed from the Centre for Girls’ Education started as a mentor in 2008, working in what they call safe spaces for girls. HM In the safe spaces tents that I mentored, they include literacy and numeracy to enhance their reading and writing skills. We have issues that have to do with reproductive health and we have entrepreneurship skills too, which help these girls to be able to build their economic capacity, to want to do what they really enjoy doing in life. And they are other life skills like building their self-esteem, being able to negotiate with their parents on issues that have to do with maybe getting them married or getting them dropped out of school. And in the safe space too, we do this leadership training where girls become cascading mentors to other younger girls. LF In September UN member states adopted the 17 sustainable development goals, one of which is dedicated to achieving gender equality. How will the SDGs help to get more women into power and break the glass ceiling? Yannick Glemarec from UN Women. YG For the first time we have a universal normative framework that applies as much to the north in these countries than the south, that covers all the dimension of sustainable development; that has the ambition to “leave no one behind”. And so this universal agenda, de facto, is a very strong commitment to gender equality and the women empowerment. One of the 17 sustainable development goals is dedicated to gender equality and women empowerment, and, in addition, we have specific target in almost every single SDG to mainstream gender equality and women empowerment in our work in every culture, in nutrition, in climate change, in infrastructure, etc. LF Suha Ziyada from the Shoruq Organisation in Palestine believes that in patriarchal societies women must be educated about their rights. SZ Since our society is a patriarchal society, it’s really important to involve men in taking action and advocating for women’s rights – because it’s a society controlled by men, and if they don’t do change, who else is doing it? So it’s important to engage men at really young ages to be involved in decision-making, or to be taught about women’s rights and about how can they be active in the society and change it for a better future for women’s rights. YG Men can be a barrier if they believe that women empowerment means that somebody is to gain – women – and somebody is to lose – men. And that’s the reason why it’s extremely important to engage men and boys in the fostering of gender equality and women empowerment, making clear that when we speak about women empowerment we do not speak about a zero-sum game, we speak about a win-win option. Countries where women are in power are richer, healthier, more stable, happier; and the best way to basically remove the fears from some men that they are about to lose something is to engage them into this overall change management process. Your young woman is supporting a major campaign and the objective of the campaign is to basically reach out to men and boys and get them to make the commitment in terms of what they can do to support gender equality and women empowerment. And it’s a very, very successful campaign. LF Let’s hear from Felicite Rwemalika. FR Start them from when they are young, tell them they’re all the same. So once they grow up, you find out in the near future we shall not have that problem again. All children will be equal and they will realise that they can make a difference. LF So what does the future look like? For example, how would having a woman as president of Fifa make a difference? IJ The mere fact that it would be female at the top, the novelty, would give the whole football world, the whole football management a new dimension, I think. I think we women, we come with a different form of management skills. I think we’re definitely more affirmative – a no is a no and a yes is a yes. I don’t think this talk in business of corruption would be so rife, if you like, if a woman were at the helm. I think with a woman at the head there would be a lot more love and understanding in the sport – yeah. LF Yannick Glemarec believes that the targets set by the SDGs on gender equality are achievable. YG What we know is that it’s not impossible. That we do have the public policy instruments. We do have the business case to achieve it. So if there is a real political will there is no reason why we could not achieve at least political parity at the national level, maybe at the local level it might take some more time. If we could physically lower the structural barriers faced by women in terms of access to the labour market, we could increase the world GDP by $12tn. That means we could increase it by over 15%. And so a number of CEOs realise that gender equality and women empowerment, it’s good business. And what we are seeing right now is that we are seeing increasingly a force to promote women in leadership positions and reduce the structural barriers that they face. HM Our president always says: “Give women a chance to choose, give them their voice, you should not choose for them.” But the country will never develop if there is a certain group of people that are left behind. So they all have to come as a community, come up, and the country will be developed. GR Hard as it is just building their capacity and their confidence to realise that in fact they can pursue whatever opportunity that they want. And I think part of that also has to do with the media, sort of demonstrating through the narrative that basically girls can participate in what they want and really highlighting the stories of girls and women who have been very successful in non-traditional fields. LF Let’s give the last word to Josephine Kulea, founder and executive director of the Sambura Girls Foundation in Kenya. JK What I’ll tell girls across the globe is: girls are powerful, girls have all it takes, and if they are just given the chance, especially those who are in school, you already have the chance, that is the only chance you need to be better than anyone out there. So you have the platform, use it well and do what your heart is calling you to do and follow your passion and your talents. LF That’s it from the Global development podcast this month. I’m Liz Ford and the producer is Kary Stewart. All our programmes are available on the Guardian’s website; that’s theguardian.com/global-development and on SoundCloud, iTunes and all podcasting apps. Next month we’re in Paris for the historic climate change conference. Until next month, goodbye. [Jingle: For more great downloads go to guardian.co.uk/audio]
